values.description:
The purpose of this PR is to port over the warning suppression utility of `ign-common` into `ign-cmake` to make the utility more accessible to all the ignition projects.

This branch is currently being used by [ign-plugin](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-plugin/src/NewRegistrationScheme).

Since `ign-plugin` requires the features of both this PR and pull request #100, I branched this off of PR #100 and I’m targeting the parent branch to make the review easier. Note that a huge portion of this PR is adding gtest. We could split that out into a separate PR to make review easier.
values.title: Warning suppression utility

summary.raw:
The purpose of this PR is to port over the warning suppression utility of `ign-common` into `ign-cmake` to make the utility more accessible to all the ignition projects.

This branch is currently being used by [ign-plugin](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-plugin/src/NewRegistrationScheme).

Since `ign-plugin` requires the features of both this PR and pull request #100, I branched this off of PR #100 and I’m targeting the parent branch to make the review easier. Note that a huge portion of this PR is adding gtest. We could split that out into a separate PR to make review easier.
summary.html:
The purpose of this PR is to port over the warning suppression utility of ign-common into ign-cmake to make the utility more accessible to all the ignition projects.

This branch is currently being used by ign-plugin.

Since ign-plugin requires the features of both this PR and pull request #100, I branched this off of PR #100 and I’m targeting the parent branch to make the review easier. Note that a huge portion of this PR is adding gtest. We could split that out into a separate PR to make review easier.

values.description:
This pull request combines tutorials with the main API documentation page. It’s easier for navigation and finding tutorials.

An ignition library can also specify custom API and Tutorial main pages.

Example: [#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/pull-requests/282/doxygen-combine-tutorials/diff](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/pull-requests/282/doxygen-combine-tutorials/diff)
values.title: Doxygen combine tutorials with main doxygen page

values.description: Fix the customization of results from cmake OGRE upstream \(from vcpkg\). Full path to Ogre libraries that are not in that form \(all the componentes, no OgreMain\).
values.title: Fix FindIgnOGRE windows support

summary.raw: Fix the customization of results from cmake OGRE upstream \(from vcpkg\). Full path to Ogre libraries that are not in that form \(all the componentes, no OgreMain\).
summary.html: Fix the customization of results from cmake OGRE upstream (from vcpkg). Full path to Ogre libraries that are not in that form (all the componentes, no OgreMain).

values.description:
This PR addresses issue #44.

Now `ign-cmake` will create and install a pkgconfig file for itself so that dependent projects can find the `ignition-cmake-utilities` headers.

All ignition projects that configure off of these changes will have `ignition-cmake# > 1.1` added to their own pkgconfig files to ensure that their downstream dependents will be able to see the location of the utility headers, which will most likely be used in the ignition project's public API headers. This is a bit of a blunt instrument since almost none of the ignition projects are actually using the utilities headers yet, but the alternative would be to have each project explicitly opt-in to adding the `ignition-cmake` entry to their pkgconfig, and I’m afraid that approach would be very error-prone.
values.title: Create a pkgconfig file for ignition-cmake so that utilities headers can be found by dependents

summary.raw:
This PR addresses issue #44.

Now `ign-cmake` will create and install a pkgconfig file for itself so that dependent projects can find the `ignition-cmake-utilities` headers.

All ignition projects that configure off of these changes will have `ignition-cmake# > 1.1` added to their own pkgconfig files to ensure that their downstream dependents will be able to see the location of the utility headers, which will most likely be used in the ignition project's public API headers. This is a bit of a blunt instrument since almost none of the ignition projects are actually using the utilities headers yet, but the alternative would be to have each project explicitly opt-in to adding the `ignition-cmake` entry to their pkgconfig, and I’m afraid that approach would be very error-prone.
summary.html:
This PR addresses issue #44.

Now ign-cmake will create and install a pkgconfig file for itself so that dependent projects can find the ignition-cmake-utilities headers.

All ignition projects that configure off of these changes will have ignition-cmake# > 1.1 added to their own pkgconfig files to ensure that their downstream dependents will be able to see the location of the utility headers, which will most likely be used in the ignition project's public API headers. This is a bit of a blunt instrument since almost none of the ignition projects are actually using the utilities headers yet, but the alternative would be to have each project explicitly opt-in to adding the ignition-cmake entry to their pkgconfig, and I’m afraid that approach would be very error-prone.

values.description:
The [OGRE\_RESOURCE\_PATH](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-cmake/src/0a83df0a027842f4df1ff7d237b3d7c9f1058c4f/cmake/FindIgnOGRE.cmake#lines-34) was missing on windows and had to be set in order for ign-rendering to find the ogre plugins.

[jenkins ign\_rendering\_win build](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ign_render_win/224/) shows that some tests are now passing as ogre and its plugins can be loaded on Windows.

I also fixed resetting pkg-config path for linux in [0a83df0](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-cmake/commits/0a83df0a027842f4df1ff7d237b3d7c9f1058c4f) as it was only being reset if ogre was found.
values.title: Set ogre resource path on windows

summary.raw:
The [OGRE\_RESOURCE\_PATH](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-cmake/src/0a83df0a027842f4df1ff7d237b3d7c9f1058c4f/cmake/FindIgnOGRE.cmake#lines-34) was missing on windows and had to be set in order for ign-rendering to find the ogre plugins.

[jenkins ign\_rendering\_win build](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ign_render_win/224/) shows that some tests are now passing as ogre and its plugins can be loaded on Windows.

I also fixed resetting pkg-config path for linux in [0a83df0](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-cmake/commits/0a83df0a027842f4df1ff7d237b3d7c9f1058c4f) as it was only being reset if ogre was found.
summary.html:
The OGRE_RESOURCE_PATH was missing on windows and had to be set in order for ign-rendering to find the ogre plugins.

jenkins ign_rendering_win build shows that some tests are now passing as ogre and its plugins can be loaded on Windows.

I also fixed resetting pkg-config path for linux in 0a83df0 as it was only being reset if ogre was found.

values.title: use IGN_BUILD_WARNING not BUILD_WARNING in Find*OGRE* files

values.description: This is just a guess at what might fix the Ogre packaging issues on OSX mentioned in [https://github.com/osrf/homebrew-simulation/pull/457#issuecomment-410312071](https://github.com/osrf/homebrew-simulation/pull/457#issuecomment-410312071). I am in the process of testing it still to confirm; opening for visibility in the meantime.

values.description: I had assumed ogre's plugin libraries will be installed to `[install_prefix]/lib/OGRE`. While that worked for ogre 2.1 installed from source but that's not the case for system installs. The shared libraries are installed to a versioned directory instead. So this PR adds the use of `pkg-config` to get the ogre plugin dir path.
values.title: Use pkg-config to get ogre plugin dir path

summary.raw: I had assumed ogre's plugin libraries will be installed to `[install_prefix]/lib/OGRE`. While that worked for ogre 2.1 installed from source but that's not the case for system installs. The shared libraries are installed to a versioned directory instead. So this PR adds the use of `pkg-config` to get the ogre plugin dir path.
summary.html: I had assumed ogre's plugin libraries will be installed to [install_prefix]/lib/OGRE. While that worked for ogre 2.1 installed from source but that's not the case for system installs. The shared libraries are installed to a versioned directory instead. So this PR adds the use of pkg-config to get the ogre plugin dir path.

values.description: The cpplint.py file is missing some the system header files from c++14 and c++17, which causes them to be incorrectly recognized as C headers (see #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/addon/pipelines/home#!/results/359). This adds the c++14 and c++17 headers to the _CPP_HEADERS variable in cpplint.py to match https://github.com/cpplint/cpplint/pull/48
values.title: codecheck: add c++14 and c++17 headers to _CPP_HEADERS in cpplint.py

summary.raw: The cpplint.py file is missing some the system header files from c++14 and c++17, which causes them to be incorrectly recognized as C headers (see #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/addon/pipelines/home#!/results/359). This adds the c++14 and c++17 headers to the _CPP_HEADERS variable in cpplint.py to match https://github.com/cpplint/cpplint/pull/48
summary.html: The cpplint.py file is missing some the system header files from c++14 and c++17, which causes them to be incorrectly recognized as C headers (see #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/addon/pipelines/home#!/results/359). This adds the c++14 and c++17 headers to the _CPP_HEADERS variable in cpplint.py to match https://github.com/cpplint/cpplint/pull/48

values.description:
Before:

~~~
-- BUILD ERRORS: These must be resolved before compiling.
--      Missing: ignition-math6
-- END BUILD ERRORS
~~~

After:

~~~
-- BUILD ERRORS: These must be resolved before compiling.
--      Missing: ignition-math6 (eigen3)
-- END BUILD ERRORS
~~~

I'm not sure if there's a standard way of referring to components, so I just put it in parenthesis.
values.title: [gz11] Add missing component to error message

summary.raw:
Before:

~~~
-- BUILD ERRORS: These must be resolved before compiling.
--      Missing: ignition-math6
-- END BUILD ERRORS
~~~

After:

~~~
-- BUILD ERRORS: These must be resolved before compiling.
--      Missing: ignition-math6 (eigen3)
-- END BUILD ERRORS
~~~

I'm not sure if there's a standard way of referring to components, so I just put it in parenthesis.
summary.html:
Before:

-- BUILD ERRORS: These must be resolved before compiling.
--      Missing: ignition-math6
-- END BUILD ERRORS

After:

-- BUILD ERRORS: These must be resolved before compiling.
--      Missing: ignition-math6 (eigen3)
-- END BUILD ERRORS

I'm not sure if there's a standard way of referring to components, so I just put it in parenthesis.

values.description:
Right now `ign-cmake` will emit an unnecessary developer warning about missing pkg-config information whenever an ignition dependency could not be found. This PR fixes that by skipping the developer warning whenever a dependency was not found.

If a dependency could not be found, then there’s no reason to assume that we should have its pkg-config information anyhow.
values.title: [default] Do not emit dev warning for unfound ignition packages

summary.raw:
Right now `ign-cmake` will emit an unnecessary developer warning about missing pkg-config information whenever an ignition dependency could not be found. This PR fixes that by skipping the developer warning whenever a dependency was not found.

If a dependency could not be found, then there’s no reason to assume that we should have its pkg-config information anyhow.
summary.html:
Right now ign-cmake will emit an unnecessary developer warning about missing pkg-config information whenever an ignition dependency could not be found. This PR fixes that by skipping the developer warning whenever a dependency was not found.

If a dependency could not be found, then there’s no reason to assume that we should have its pkg-config information anyhow.

values.title: [gz11] Do not emit dev warning for unfound ignition packages

summary.raw: Same as pull request #113 but targeting gz11.

values.description:
The Windows version of Ogre from `vcpkg` is not adding support to link against plugins libs \(it is present in the Linux version\) [unless you create the static version of it](https://github.com/OGRECave/ogre/blob/master/CMake/Templates/OGREConfig.cmake.in#L151). I’m copying the logic from the Config.cmake here.

Tested:

* Failing with linking problems:  \(grep for `fatal error LNK1120)`

    ![](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ign_rendering-pr-win/39//badge/icon)

    [https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ign\_rendering-pr-win/39/](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ign_rendering-pr-win/39/))


* Linking fine:

    ![](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ign_rendering-pr-win/51//badge/icon)

    [https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ign\_rendering-pr-win/51/](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ign_rendering-pr-win/51/))
values.title: Support for IgnOGRE to link against plugins libs in Windows shared version

summary.raw:
The Windows version of Ogre from `vcpkg` is not adding support to link against plugins libs \(it is present in the Linux version\) [unless you create the static version of it](https://github.com/OGRECave/ogre/blob/master/CMake/Templates/OGREConfig.cmake.in#L151). I’m copying the logic from the Config.cmake here.

Tested:

* Failing with linking problems:  \(grep for `fatal error LNK1120)`

    ![](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ign_rendering-pr-win/39//badge/icon)

    [https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ign\_rendering-pr-win/39/](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ign_rendering-pr-win/39/))


* Linking fine:

    ![](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ign_rendering-pr-win/51//badge/icon)

    [https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ign\_rendering-pr-win/51/](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ign_rendering-pr-win/51/))
summary.html:
The Windows version of Ogre from vcpkg is not adding support to link against plugins libs (it is present in the Linux version) unless you create the static version of it. I’m copying the logic from the Config.cmake here.

Tested:

  • Failing with linking problems: (grep for fatal error LNK1120)

    https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ign_rendering-pr-win/39/)

  • Linking fine:

    https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ign_rendering-pr-win/51/)

values.description: IgnConfigureProject.cmake: fix small typo PKCONFIG -> PKGCONFIG

summary.raw: IgnConfigureProject.cmake: fix small typo PKCONFIG -> PKGCONFIG
summary.html: IgnConfigureProject.cmake: fix small typo PKCONFIG -> PKGCONFIG

values.description:
It seems that a mistake was made at some point during merging, and we were left with two copies of a cmake macro, where the second one would just overwrite the first one. This is especially bad because the second version of the macro was old and out of date.

To illustrate this, without the PR we get the following pkg-config for `ignition-common3.pc`:

    prefix=/home/grey/projects/gz11/install/ignition-common3
    libdir=${prefix}/lib
    includedir=${prefix}/include/ignition/common3
    
    Name: Ignition common
    Description: A set of common classes for robot applications
    Version: 3.0.0
    Requires: ignition-cmake2 >= 1.1 uuid
    Requires.private: 
    Libs: -L${libdir} -lignition-common3 
    Libs.private: 
    CFlags: -I${includedir} -std=c++14

With this PR, we get this instead:

    prefix=/home/grey/projects/gz11/install/ignition-common3
    libdir=${prefix}/lib
    includedir=${prefix}/include/ignition/common3
    
    Name: Ignition common
    Description: A set of common classes for robot applications
    Version: 3.0.0
    Requires: ignition-cmake2 >= 1.1 uuid
    Requires.private: 
    Libs: -L${libdir} -lignition-common3 -ldl
    Libs.private: 
    CFlags: -I${includedir} -std=c++14

Notice how `-ldl` was missing from the first.

‌

Similarly, for without the PR this is what we get for `ignition-common3-graphics.pc`:

    prefix=/home/grey/projects/gz11/install/ignition-common3
    libdir=${prefix}/lib
    includedir=${prefix}/include/ignition/common3
    
    Name: Ignition common graphics
    Description: A set of common graphics classes for robot applications
    Version: ignition-cmake2 >= 1.1 3.0.0
    Requires: ignition-math6 ignition-common3 = 3.0.0
    Requires.private: tinyxml2 gts
    Libs: -L${libdir} -lignition-common3-graphics 
    Libs.private: 
    CFLags: -I${includedir} 

With the PR we get:

    prefix=/home/grey/projects/gz11/install/ignition-common3
    libdir=${prefix}/lib
    includedir=${prefix}/include/ignition/common3
    
    Name: Ignition common graphics
    Description: A set of common graphics classes for robot applications
    Version: ignition-cmake2 >= 1.1 3.0.0
    Requires: ignition-math6 ignition-common3 = 3.0.0
    Requires.private: tinyxml2 gts
    Libs: -L${libdir} -lignition-common3-graphics 
    Libs.private: -lfreeimage
    CFLags: -I${includedir} 

Notice that `-lfreeimage` was missing from the first one.
values.title: Remove an outdated version of a cmake macro

summary.raw:
It seems that a mistake was made at some point during merging, and we were left with two copies of a cmake macro, where the second one would just overwrite the first one. This is especially bad because the second version of the macro was old and out of date.

To illustrate this, without the PR we get the following pkg-config for `ignition-common3.pc`:

Similarly, for without the PR this is what we get for `ignition-common3-graphics.pc`:

With the PR we get:

Notice that `-lfreeimage` was missing from the first one.
summary.html:
It seems that a mistake was made at some point during merging, and we were left with two copies of a cmake macro, where the second one would just overwrite the first one. This is especially bad because the second version of the macro was old and out of date.

To illustrate this, without the PR we get the following pkg-config for ignition-common3.pc:

prefix=/home/grey/projects/gz11/install/ignition-common3
libdir=${prefix}/lib
includedir=${prefix}/include/ignition/common3

Name: Ignition common
Description: A set of common classes for robot applications
Version: 3.0.0
Requires: ignition-cmake2 >= 1.1 uuid
Requires.private: 
Libs: -L${libdir} -lignition-common3 
Libs.private: 
CFlags: -I${includedir} -std=c++14

With this PR, we get this instead:

prefix=/home/grey/projects/gz11/install/ignition-common3
libdir=${prefix}/lib
includedir=${prefix}/include/ignition/common3

Name: Ignition common
Description: A set of common classes for robot applications
Version: 3.0.0
Requires: ignition-cmake2 >= 1.1 uuid
Requires.private: 
Libs: -L${libdir} -lignition-common3 -ldl
Libs.private: 
CFlags: -I${includedir} -std=c++14

Notice how -ldl was missing from the first.

‌

Similarly, for without the PR this is what we get for ignition-common3-graphics.pc:

prefix=/home/grey/projects/gz11/install/ignition-common3
libdir=${prefix}/lib
includedir=${prefix}/include/ignition/common3

Name: Ignition common graphics
Description: A set of common graphics classes for robot applications
Version: ignition-cmake2 >= 1.1 3.0.0
Requires: ignition-math6 ignition-common3 = 3.0.0
Requires.private: tinyxml2 gts
Libs: -L${libdir} -lignition-common3-graphics 
Libs.private: 
CFLags: -I${includedir}

With the PR we get:

prefix=/home/grey/projects/gz11/install/ignition-common3
libdir=${prefix}/lib
includedir=${prefix}/include/ignition/common3

Name: Ignition common graphics
Description: A set of common graphics classes for robot applications
Version: ignition-cmake2 >= 1.1 3.0.0
Requires: ignition-math6 ignition-common3 = 3.0.0
Requires.private: tinyxml2 gts
Libs: -L${libdir} -lignition-common3-graphics 
Libs.private: -lfreeimage
CFLags: -I${includedir}

Notice that -lfreeimage was missing from the first one.

values.description:
As noted in #46, lcov fails to exclude irrelevant files in our gz11 branches. This adjusts the search pattern to ensure that gtest and other test files are excluded.

Tested in ign-math:

* #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/branch/test_coverage_lcov_1.13
* ![test_coverage_lcov_1.13 coverage](https://codecov.io/bb/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/branch/test_coverage_lcov_1.13/graph/badge.svg) https://codecov.io/bb/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/branch/test_coverage_lcov_1.13

This does require an adjustment to the pipelines scripts in downstream repositories.

Also, this isn't a complete fix, there's still an [issue with lcov](https://github.com/linux-test-project/lcov/issues/41) that @azeey discovered.
values.title: fix lcov search pattern to work with version 1.13

summary.raw:
As noted in #46, lcov fails to exclude irrelevant files in our gz11 branches. This adjusts the search pattern to ensure that gtest and other test files are excluded.

Tested in ign-math:

* #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/branch/test_coverage_lcov_1.13
* ![test_coverage_lcov_1.13 coverage](https://codecov.io/bb/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/branch/test_coverage_lcov_1.13/graph/badge.svg) https://codecov.io/bb/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/branch/test_coverage_lcov_1.13

This does require an adjustment to the pipelines scripts in downstream repositories.

Also, this isn't a complete fix, there's still an [issue with lcov](https://github.com/linux-test-project/lcov/issues/41) that @azeey discovered.

This does require an adjustment to the pipelines scripts in downstream repositories.

Also, this isn't a complete fix, there's still an issue with lcov that @azeey discovered.

summary.html: This introduces a new and improved README to ignition-cmake, building off of the template used by ignition-gazebo.

values.description:
New libogre-2.1\* debs have been uploaded onto [packages.osrfoundation.org](http://packages.osrfoundation.org/gazebo/ubuntu-prerelease/dists/bionic/main/binary-amd64/Packages) \(pre-release repo, bionic only\). They can now be installed side-by-side with ogre1.x. The main changes in this PR are:

* Updated pkg-config logic to look for OGRE-2.1 \(new debs install .pc file with version suffix\)
* Added IgnOGRE::IgnOgre and IgnOGRE2::IgnOGRE2 targets
* Renamed FindOGRE2.cmake to FindIgnOGRE2.cmake to be consistent with FindIgnOGRE.cmake
values.title: Update FindOgre2 to work with new debs

summary.raw:
New libogre-2.1\* debs have been uploaded onto [packages.osrfoundation.org](http://packages.osrfoundation.org/gazebo/ubuntu-prerelease/dists/bionic/main/binary-amd64/Packages) \(pre-release repo, bionic only\). They can now be installed side-by-side with ogre1.x. The main changes in this PR are:

* Updated pkg-config logic to look for OGRE-2.1 \(new debs install .pc file with version suffix\)
* Added IgnOGRE::IgnOgre and IgnOGRE2::IgnOGRE2 targets
* Renamed FindOGRE2.cmake to FindIgnOGRE2.cmake to be consistent with FindIgnOGRE.cmake
summary.html:
New libogre-2.1* debs have been uploaded onto packages.osrfoundation.org (pre-release repo, bionic only). They can now be installed side-by-side with ogre1.x. The main changes in this PR are:

  • Updated pkg-config logic to look for OGRE-2.1 (new debs install .pc file with version suffix)
  • Added IgnOGRE::IgnOgre and IgnOGRE2::IgnOGRE2 targets
  • Renamed FindOGRE2.cmake to FindIgnOGRE2.cmake to be consistent with FindIgnOGRE.cmake

values.description:
The problem was the manipulation of variable with multiple configurations on them \(i.e:`C:/vcpkg/installed/x64-windows$<$<CONFIG:Debug>:/debug>/..`\) . The solution is a dirty workaround but I did not found a better way of checking absolute paths with that kind of variables than comparing the first characters of the paths.

With this fix, ign-gui is able to compile just fine:

* [https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/All/job/ign\_gui-pr-win/24/](https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/All/job/ign_gui-pr-win/24)

Easier diff: [#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-cmake/pull-requests/125/hack-not-to-modify-absolute-path-libraries/diff?w=1](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-cmake/pull-requests/125/hack-not-to-modify-absolute-path-libraries/diff?w=1)
values.title: Hack not to modify absolute path libraries in FindIgnOGRE on Windows

summary.raw:
The problem was the manipulation of variable with multiple configurations on them \(i.e:`C:/vcpkg/installed/x64-windows$<$<CONFIG:Debug>:/debug>/..`\) . The solution is a dirty workaround but I did not found a better way of checking absolute paths with that kind of variables than comparing the first characters of the paths.

With this fix, ign-gui is able to compile just fine:

* [https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/All/job/ign\_gui-pr-win/24/](https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/All/job/ign_gui-pr-win/24)

Easier diff: [#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-cmake/pull-requests/125/hack-not-to-modify-absolute-path-libraries/diff?w=1](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-cmake/pull-requests/125/hack-not-to-modify-absolute-path-libraries/diff?w=1)
summary.html:
The problem was the manipulation of variable with multiple configurations on them (i.e:C:/vcpkg/installed/x64-windows$<$<CONFIG:Debug>:/debug>/..) . The solution is a dirty workaround but I did not found a better way of checking absolute paths with that kind of variables than comparing the first characters of the paths.

With this fix, ign-gui is able to compile just fine:

  • https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/All/job/ign_gui-pr-win/24/

Easier diff: #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-cmake/pull-requests/125/hack-not-to-modify-absolute-path-libraries/diff?w=1

values.description: Turns out `PKG_NAME` conflicts with a reserved variable that's use internally throughout cmake. Any ignition library that calls `ign_find_pkg(IgnOGRE2 ...)` may result in cmake files with incorrect package name generated, e.g. `ignition-rendering1-config.cmake` sets package name to `OGRE-2.1` instead of `ignition-rendering1`
values.title: Fix FindIgnOGRE2 overriding PKG_NAME

summary.raw: Turns out `PKG_NAME` conflicts with a reserved variable that's use internally throughout cmake. Any ignition library that calls `ign_find_pkg(IgnOGRE2 ...)` may result in cmake files with incorrect package name generated, e.g. `ignition-rendering1-config.cmake` sets package name to `OGRE-2.1` instead of `ignition-rendering1`
summary.html: Turns out PKG_NAME conflicts with a reserved variable that's use internally throughout cmake. Any ignition library that calls ign_find_pkg(IgnOGRE2 ...) may result in cmake files with incorrect package name generated, e.g. ignition-rendering1-config.cmake sets package name to OGRE-2.1 instead of ignition-rendering1

values.title: Prepare for 2.0.0 pre3 release

values.description: As discussed in #48, if a package has components with a dependency relationship (such as ign-physics-dartsim-plugin, which depends on ignition-physics-sdf and ignition-physics-mesh), then then all the components must be listed in the ign_find_package call and in a proper order. This pull request includes an example of this issue in which components are specified in the proper order. The failing case is included in a separate branch ([find_component_order](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-cmake/branch/find_component_order?dest=find_component_order_working#diff)) that only differs in the order in which components are specified in the `ign_find_package` call.
values.title: Working example for issue #48 (find component order)

summary.raw: As discussed in #48, if a package has components with a dependency relationship (such as ign-physics-dartsim-plugin, which depends on ignition-physics-sdf and ignition-physics-mesh), then then all the components must be listed in the ign_find_package call and in a proper order. This pull request includes an example of this issue in which components are specified in the proper order. The failing case is included in a separate branch ([find_component_order](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-cmake/branch/find_component_order?dest=find_component_order_working#diff)) that only differs in the order in which components are specified in the `ign_find_package` call.
summary.html: As discussed in #48, if a package has components with a dependency relationship (such as ign-physics-dartsim-plugin, which depends on ignition-physics-sdf and ignition-physics-mesh), then then all the components must be listed in the ign_find_package call and in a proper order. This pull request includes an example of this issue in which components are specified in the proper order. The failing case is included in a separate branch (find_component_order) that only differs in the order in which components are specified in the ign_find_package call.

values.description: Our `FindODE.cmake` script was assuming that we want to use `dSingle` for to have 32-bit floating point precision, which is not a safe assumption. Injecting this into the cmake script causes a considerable amount of trouble for downstream users who don’t want that setting.
values.title: Do not assume that users want dSingle precision for ODE

summary.raw: Our `FindODE.cmake` script was assuming that we want to use `dSingle` for to have 32-bit floating point precision, which is not a safe assumption. Injecting this into the cmake script causes a considerable amount of trouble for downstream users who don’t want that setting.
summary.html: Our FindODE.cmake script was assuming that we want to use dSingle for to have 32-bit floating point precision, which is not a safe assumption. Injecting this into the cmake script causes a considerable amount of trouble for downstream users who don’t want that setting.

values.description:
Note that this builds off of pull request #129, so that should be reviewed\+merged first.

This resolves a perplexing build configuration issue that came up when dartsim switched to using imported targets \(which is a positive development, but it unearthed some weird build system behavior\).

Basically our use of `pkg_check_modules(TINYXML2 ...)` was polluting the cmake cache with deceptive variables because `pkg-config` tries to be too smart and leaves `/usr/include` out of the paths that reports as include directories for packages. This left the variable `TINYXML2_INCLUDE_DIRS` as a blank cache entry. Then when dartsim attempted to call `find_path(TINYXML2_INCLUDE_DIRS ...)` in its own find-module, the `find_path(~)` function believed that the include directory was already found, and that it's meant to be an empty string. But when dartsim got back an empty string from `find_path(~)` it gets interpreted as a failure to find `tinyxml2.h`, and then the configuration is believed to have failed.

This is a brute force attempt to correct that issue \(and other potentially similar issues in the future\) by clearing the `<prefix>_INCLUDE_DIRS` cache variable created by `pkg_check_module(~)` if that variable is blank. I left a TODO for a potentially more elegant way to fix this, but the more elegant way would also be more invasive, so I’m leaving it as future work.
values.title: Unset blank cache variables

summary.raw:
Note that this builds off of pull request #129, so that should be reviewed\+merged first.

This resolves a perplexing build configuration issue that came up when dartsim switched to using imported targets \(which is a positive development, but it unearthed some weird build system behavior\).

Basically our use of `pkg_check_modules(TINYXML2 ...)` was polluting the cmake cache with deceptive variables because `pkg-config` tries to be too smart and leaves `/usr/include` out of the paths that reports as include directories for packages. This left the variable `TINYXML2_INCLUDE_DIRS` as a blank cache entry. Then when dartsim attempted to call `find_path(TINYXML2_INCLUDE_DIRS ...)` in its own find-module, the `find_path(~)` function believed that the include directory was already found, and that it's meant to be an empty string. But when dartsim got back an empty string from `find_path(~)` it gets interpreted as a failure to find `tinyxml2.h`, and then the configuration is believed to have failed.

This is a brute force attempt to correct that issue \(and other potentially similar issues in the future\) by clearing the `<prefix>_INCLUDE_DIRS` cache variable created by `pkg_check_module(~)` if that variable is blank. I left a TODO for a potentially more elegant way to fix this, but the more elegant way would also be more invasive, so I’m leaving it as future work.
summary.html:
Note that this builds off of pull request #129, so that should be reviewed+merged first.

This resolves a perplexing build configuration issue that came up when dartsim switched to using imported targets (which is a positive development, but it unearthed some weird build system behavior).

Basically our use of pkg_check_modules(TINYXML2 ...) was polluting the cmake cache with deceptive variables because pkg-config tries to be too smart and leaves /usr/include out of the paths that reports as include directories for packages. This left the variable TINYXML2_INCLUDE_DIRS as a blank cache entry. Then when dartsim attempted to call find_path(TINYXML2_INCLUDE_DIRS ...) in its own find-module, the find_path(~) function believed that the include directory was already found, and that it's meant to be an empty string. But when dartsim got back an empty string from find_path(~) it gets interpreted as a failure to find tinyxml2.h, and then the configuration is believed to have failed.

This is a brute force attempt to correct that issue (and other potentially similar issues in the future) by clearing the <prefix>_INCLUDE_DIRS cache variable created by pkg_check_module(~) if that variable is blank. I left a TODO for a potentially more elegant way to fix this, but the more elegant way would also be more invasive, so I’m leaving it as future work.

values.description:
This PR fixes issue #48. Now exported components can declare their inter-dependencies, and they will find each other when they get imported.

This does require one adjustment to downstream ignition packages: when calling `ign_add_component(~)` you must add a `COMPONENT_DEPS <component_dependency_names...>` argument to the function call.

Note that I'm open to a different argument name than `COMPONENT_DEPS` if anyone has any other suggestions.
values.title: Account for inter-component dependencies when importing targets

summary.raw:
This PR fixes issue #48. Now exported components can declare their inter-dependencies, and they will find each other when they get imported.

This does require one adjustment to downstream ignition packages: when calling `ign_add_component(~)` you must add a `COMPONENT_DEPS <component_dependency_names...>` argument to the function call.

Note that I'm open to a different argument name than `COMPONENT_DEPS` if anyone has any other suggestions.
summary.html:
This PR fixes issue #48. Now exported components can declare their inter-dependencies, and they will find each other when they get imported.

This does require one adjustment to downstream ignition packages: when calling ign_add_component(~) you must add a COMPONENT_DEPS <component_dependency_names...> argument to the function call.

Note that I'm open to a different argument name than COMPONENT_DEPS if anyone has any other suggestions.

values.description:
There are a few places that generate stderr output, which causes a "yellow" build in tools like `colcon`.

Primarily, this happens when doing some sort of parallel invocation of cmake/make, and generates:  

    (ign_ws)➜  ign_ws colcon build --packages-select ignition-cmake2
    Starting >>> ignition-cmake2
    --- stderr: ignition-cmake2                                  
    make[3]: warning: jobserver unavailable: using -j1.  Add '+' to parent make rule.
    .....
    make[4]: warning: jobserver unavailable: using -j1.  Add '+' to parent make rule.
    ---
    Finished <<< ignition-cmake2 [16.7s]
values.title: Clean up some unnecessary stderr output

values.description:
We recently added some examples in pull request #131 that run successfully on the jenkins jobs that use `NMake Makefiles` for the cmake generator:

* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=ignition_cmake-ci-gz11-windows7-amd64&build=15)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_cmake-ci-gz11-windows7-amd64/15/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_cmake-ci-gz11-windows7-amd64/15/

but they fail due to excessive path lengths in a colcon build that uses Visual Studio for its cmake generator:

* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=ign_physics-ci-win&build=56)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ign_physics-ci-win/56/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ign_physics-ci-win/56/

Rather than try to figure out why, I've just disabled those new examples if the `CMAKE_GENERATOR` matches `Visual Studio`. I've tested it with a custom gazebodistro branch to confirm the fix:

* https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebodistro/branch/visual_studio_disable_examples#diff
* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=ign_physics-ci-win&build=58)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ign_physics-ci-win/58/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ign_physics-ci-win/58/
values.title: Disable some examples due to path name length problems with Visual Studio generator is used

We recently added some examples in pull request #131 that run successfully on the jenkins jobs that use `NMake Makefiles` for the cmake generator:

* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=ignition_cmake-ci-gz11-windows7-amd64&build=15)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_cmake-ci-gz11-windows7-amd64/15/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_cmake-ci-gz11-windows7-amd64/15/

but they fail due to excessive path lengths in a colcon build that uses Visual Studio for its cmake generator:

* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=ign_physics-ci-win&build=56)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ign_physics-ci-win/56/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ign_physics-ci-win/56/

Rather than try to figure out why, I've just disabled those new examples if the `CMAKE_GENERATOR` matches `Visual Studio`. I've tested it with a custom gazebodistro branch to confirm the fix:

* https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebodistro/branch/visual_studio_disable_examples#diff
* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=ign_physics-ci-win&build=58)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ign_physics-ci-win/58/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ign_physics-ci-win/58/
summary.html:
We recently added some examples in pull request #131 that run successfully on the jenkins jobs that use NMake Makefiles for the cmake generator:

  • https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_cmake-ci-gz11-windows7-amd64/15/

but they fail due to excessive path lengths in a colcon build that uses Visual Studio for its cmake generator:

  • https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ign_physics-ci-win/56/

Rather than try to figure out why, I've just disabled those new examples if the CMAKE_GENERATOR matches Visual Studio. I've tested it with a custom gazebodistro branch to confirm the fix:

  • https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebodistro/branch/visual_studio_disable_examples#diff
  • https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ign_physics-ci-win/58/

values.description: CMakeLists.txt: bump to 1.0.0~pre4
values.title: CMakeLists.txt: bump to 1.0.0~pre4

summary.raw: CMakeLists.txt: bump to 1.0.0~pre4
summary.html: CMakeLists.txt: bump to 1.0.0~pre4

values.description:
There is a weird race condition in building some of the cmake examples because they have a number in the project name that gets stripped out, so they end up having Export.hh header files with identical install paths. If two examples happen to be at the install step at the same they can cause the build to fail:

* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=ignition_cmake-ci-gz11-homebrew-amd64&build=14)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_cmake-ci-gz11-homebrew-amd64/14/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_cmake-ci-gz11-homebrew-amd64/14/

~~~
CMake Error at src/cmake_install.cmake:36 (file):
  file INSTALL cannot set modification time on
  "/Users/jenkins/workspace/ignition_cmake-ci-gz11-homebrew-amd64/build/install/Debug/include/ignition/use_component_deps0/ignition/use_component_deps/detail/Export.hh"
Call Stack (most recent call first):
  cmake_install.cmake:64 (include)
...
make[3]: *** [install] Error 1
*** [examples/use_component_deps3_Debug-prefix/src/use_component_deps3_Debug-stamp/use_component_deps3_Debug-install] Error 2
make[1]: *** [examples/CMakeFiles/use_component_deps3_Debug.dir/all] Error 2
make[1]: *** Waiting for unfinished jobs....
~~~

This pull request first backports a Visual Studio fix from pull request #134 and then renames the `use_component_deps[123]` examples to `use_component_deps[ABC]` (1 -> A, 2 -> B, 3 -> C). It is enough to give unique paths to the Export.hh files and fix this race condition.
values.title: Fix race condition: rename use_component_deps[123] examples to use_component_deps[ABC]

If two examples happen to be at the install step at the same they can cause the build to fail:

values.description:
This merges gz11 branch back to default. We can then create the official ign-cmake2 release branch and then create the debian release of ign-cmake2.

This will drop xenial support for all subsequent releases. The ign-cmake1 release branch still supports xenial.
values.title: Gz11 to default

summary.raw:
This merges gz11 branch back to default. We can then create the official ign-cmake2 release branch and then create the debian release of ign-cmake2.

This will drop xenial support for all subsequent releases. The ign-cmake1 release branch still supports xenial.
summary.html:
This merges gz11 branch back to default. We can then create the official ign-cmake2 release branch and then create the debian release of ign-cmake2.

This will drop xenial support for all subsequent releases. The ign-cmake1 release branch still supports xenial.

values.description:
I have a case where there is no project lib and there is a component that has tests. When building the tests, I need to indicate that the tests should not link against the project lib which doesn't exist.

Here is the PR that needs this PR: #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-tools/pull-requests/6
values.title: Allow tests to build without automatic linking against project lib

summary.raw:

values.description:
While looking at install ign-gazebo world files I noticed that we are installing a lot of data into `share` in an inconsistent manner. Take a look at your `share` folder and you'll see things like `ignition-transport6` and `ignition-transport6_0`. 

This PR is a step toward consistency by removing the minor version from doxygen tagfiles. I don't believe the minor version is necessary when installing tag files.
values.title: Update datainstall dir

summary.raw:
While looking at install ign-gazebo world files I noticed that we are installing a lot of data into `share` in an inconsistent manner. Take a look at your `share` folder and you'll see things like `ignition-transport6` and `ignition-transport6_0`. 

This PR is a step toward consistency by removing the minor version from doxygen tagfiles. I don't believe the minor version is necessary when installing tag files.
summary.html:
While looking at install ign-gazebo world files I noticed that we are installing a lot of data into share in an inconsistent manner. Take a look at your share folder and you'll see things like ignition-transport6 and ignition-transport6_0.

This PR is a step toward consistency by removing the minor version from doxygen tagfiles. I don't believe the minor version is necessary when installing tag files.

values.description:
The comments in `IgnCreateDocs.cmake` explain the problem and the solution.

To test:

1. Install ign-math.
2. Create docs for ign-msgs.
3. `firefox doxygen/html/tutorials.html` will not exist in the `ign-msgs` build folder.
4. Now generate ign-math docs using this PR.
5. Regenerate the ign-msgs docs, and you should now see the tutorials.
values.title: Fix tagfile generation by preventing the inclusion of tutorials

summary.raw:

summary.html:
The comments in IgnCreateDocs.cmake explain the problem and the solution.

To test:

  1. Install ign-math.
  2. Create docs for ign-msgs.
  3. firefox doxygen/html/tutorials.html will not exist in the ign-msgs build folder.
  4. Now generate ign-math docs using this PR.
  5. Regenerate the ign-msgs docs, and you should now see the tutorials.

values.description: While working on the documentation upload script I found that we were not using dry-run for the first s3 sync command, and I need to pass in y/n to the upload script.
values.title: Actually use dry-run, and allow the user to pass in a 'y' or 'n'

summary.raw: While working on the documentation upload script I found that we were not using dry-run for the first s3 sync command, and I need to pass in y/n to the upload script.
summary.html: While working on the documentation upload script I found that we were not using dry-run for the first s3 sync command, and I need to pass in y/n to the upload script.

values.description:
When calling `ign_find_package`, when a component is specified as both `REQUIRED_BY` and `PRIVATE_FOR`, it should not be propagated as a transitive dependency in pkg-config and cmake config files. The code currently handles `PRIVATE_FOR` for pkg-config but not cmake, as noticed in a recent ign-sensors pull request:

* #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-sensors/pull-requests/51/updating-dependencies/commits

The ign-sensors pipeline [installs `libignition-common3-dev`](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-sensors/src/fe0232e17b05b8ee835c8aac4dd48058956c5288/bitbucket-pipelines.yml?at=update_deps&fileviewer=file-view-default#bitbucket-pipelines.yml-25) but not the graphics sub-component. The pipeline still failed though, wanting to find freeimage, which is [PRIVATE_FOR that component](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/src/357d22cce10e238ce1f257c9be5acb7cfd4a6ed1/CMakeLists.txt?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#CMakeLists.txt-79:81).

* #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-sensors/commits/fe0232e17b05b8ee835c8aac4dd48058956c5288?at=default

This sets the `${component}_${PACKAGE_NAME}_PRIVATE` variables earlier, so they can be used by cmake as well as pkg-config, and skips private dependencies for cmake.

I'm not sure how to write a test for this.
values.title: Use PRIVATE_FOR to skip cmake dependencies in addition to pkg-config

summary.raw:
When calling `ign_find_package`, when a component is specified as both `REQUIRED_BY` and `PRIVATE_FOR`, it should not be propagated as a transitive dependency in pkg-config and cmake config files. The code currently handles `PRIVATE_FOR` for pkg-config but not cmake, as noticed in a recent ign-sensors pull request:

* #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-sensors/pull-requests/51/updating-dependencies/commits

The ign-sensors pipeline [installs `libignition-common3-dev`](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-sensors/src/fe0232e17b05b8ee835c8aac4dd48058956c5288/bitbucket-pipelines.yml?at=update_deps&fileviewer=file-view-default#bitbucket-pipelines.yml-25) but not the graphics sub-component. The pipeline still failed though, wanting to find freeimage, which is [PRIVATE_FOR that component](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/src/357d22cce10e238ce1f257c9be5acb7cfd4a6ed1/CMakeLists.txt?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#CMakeLists.txt-79:81).

* #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-sensors/commits/fe0232e17b05b8ee835c8aac4dd48058956c5288?at=default

This sets the `${component}_${PACKAGE_NAME}_PRIVATE` variables earlier, so they can be used by cmake as well as pkg-config, and skips private dependencies for cmake.

I'm not sure how to write a test for this.
summary.html:
When calling ign_find_package, when a component is specified as both REQUIRED_BY and PRIVATE_FOR, it should not be propagated as a transitive dependency in pkg-config and cmake config files. The code currently handles PRIVATE_FOR for pkg-config but not cmake, as noticed in a recent ign-sensors pull request:

  • #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-sensors/pull-requests/51/updating-dependencies/commits

The ign-sensors pipeline installs libignition-common3-dev but not the graphics sub-component. The pipeline still failed though, wanting to find freeimage, which is PRIVATE_FOR that component.

  • #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-sensors/commits/fe0232e17b05b8ee835c8aac4dd48058956c5288?at=default

This sets the ${component}_${PACKAGE_NAME}_PRIVATE variables earlier, so they can be used by cmake as well as pkg-config, and skips private dependencies for cmake.

I'm not sure how to write a test for this.

values.description:
This is currently used by the benchmark aggregation tooling.

To use this in a project, call the `ign_add_run_benchmarks_target` function on the list of benchmark targets available in the project:

```
ign_build_executables(
  PREFIX "${TEST_TYPE}_"
  SOURCES ${tests}
  LIB_DEPS benchmark::benchmark
  EXEC_LIST benchmark_list
)

include(IgnBenchmark)
ign_add_run_benchmarks_target(TARGETS ${benchmark_list})
```

‌

This will then add a `run_benchmarks` target, that can be invoked with `make run_benchmarks`, which will execute all benchmarks and then aggregate the results into a tarfile to be stored/analyzed.
values.title: Add benchmark aggregation functionality

summary.raw:
This is currently used by the benchmark aggregation tooling.

To use this in a project, call the `ign_add_run_benchmarks_target` function on the list of benchmark targets available in the project:

```
ign_build_executables(

  SOURCES ${tests}
  LIB_DEPS benchmark::benchmark

include(IgnBenchmark)
```

‌

This will then add a `run_benchmarks` target, that can be invoked with `make run_benchmarks`, which will execute all benchmarks and then aggregate the results into a tarfile to be stored/analyzed.
summary.html:
This is currently used by the benchmark aggregation tooling.

To use this in a project, call the ign_add_run_benchmarks_target function on the list of benchmark targets available in the project:

ign_build_executables(
  PREFIX "${TEST_TYPE}_"
  SOURCES ${tests}
  LIB_DEPS benchmark::benchmark
  EXEC_LIST benchmark_list
)

include(IgnBenchmark)
ign_add_run_benchmarks_target(TARGETS ${benchmark_list})

‌

This will then add a run_benchmarks target, that can be invoked with make run_benchmarks, which will execute all benchmarks and then aggregate the results into a tarfile to be stored/analyzed.

values.description: Bump the minor in preparation for a 2.1.0 release, and add a changelog since we didn't have one. I filled it in a bit going back to 0.4.0, but I skipped a couple of the larger lists and just gave a link to the bitbucket comparison list of pull requests.
